subject: Re: [junit] Alphabetizing test method run order?
msgSnippet: At present if you create a Request, the tests will be unsorted, but you can call Request r; r.sort( new Comparator() { ... } ); to have the tests sorted.

At present if you create a Request, the tests will be unsorted, but you can=
 call

Request r;
r.sort( new Comparator() { ... } );

to have the tests so=
rted.

Additionally, a Runner has the ability to sort its tests initially,
=
though IMHO there is a tad missing in terms of sorting if your Runner
exten=
ds from ParentRunner as the entire list of tests is hidden from
the Sortabl=
e interface and child classes of ParentRunner... thus you
are relying on Co=
llections.sort to establish your sorting with the
comparator.

i.e. Some so=
rting requirements may need as many as N*N/2 comparisons
to establish the c=
orrect sorting, while Collections.sort will
typically only perform N*log(N)=
 comparisons.

See https://github.com/KentBeck/junit/pull/316

Something si=
milar to https://github.com/KentBeck/junit/pull/316 will
probably be needed=
 if/as more people use the Request#sort(Comparator)
method.

On 20 Septembe=
r 2011 08:44, Malte Finsterwalder
<malte@...> wrote:
> +1
>
=
> keep ordering undefined.
> Allow ordering though a custom Annotation, a R=
unner or a Rule (or a
> combination thereof, whatever makes sense).
>
